moves.1. f4: Bird's opening. I use it myself sometimes.
moves.1... d5 2. d4: Not the best move. the main lines here are 2.g3 and 2.e3 (2.b3 is similar to 1.b3 openenig).
moves.2... b6:
What's the point?
The bishop can move freely on the c8-h3 diagonal, why weakening the queen-side?
moves.3. e3 Nf6 4. Nc3: 4.c3 would give white the stonewall position (like black plays in the dutch opening).
moves.4... c6 5. Nf3 Bg4: now we can see that b6 was not in place. instead black could already play Nbd7 or e6.
moves.6. Be2 Ne4: one coukd not attack with only two pieces.
moves.7. Nd2: 7. 0-0 is better. there is no real threat from the black side.
moves.7... Bxe2: It is better to take first on c3 - making doubled pawns for white.
moves.8. Nxe2 e6 9. O-O c5: Black is not yet castked and its kind of dangerous to open the center now.
moves.10. Nxe4: 10. c3 is a good option too.
moves.10... dxe4 11. Ng3 f5: black has a big problem. on the queen-side he is exposed in the white squares with no white squares bishop. in the center all his pawns are on the white squares with no real defense.
moves.12. b3: yes, the bishop's place is indeed b2.
moves.12... g5:
????
the king is exposed with no defense and black is helping white to take the a1-h8 diagonal easy.
moves.13... Bg7 14. Qh5+ Kf8 15. fxg5: black is lost. there is no escape for the king.
moves.17. Qxh7: 17. dxc5! Qe7 18. Bf6 Bxf6 19. gxf6 Qxf6 20. Nxe4! Qg7 21. g3 bxc5 22. Nxc5 Qf7 23. Qh6+ Ke8 24.Qxe6+ Qxe6 25. Nxe6 +-
moves.19... Qxe4 20. dxc5: and why giving up the bishop too?
moves.20... Qxe3+ 21. Kh1 Bxb2 22. Rd7: it seems that white has a great attack. I'm not sure of it.
moves.24... Rxg7 25. Qh8+ Kd7 26. Qxg7+ Ne7 27:
is it realy lost?
29... Kc7 30. Qd6+ Kc7 (30... Kc8 31. Qxe7 and mates the next move) 31. Qd7+ Ka6 32. b4 Qxa2 (32... Nc6 33. Ra3+ Na5 34. Rxa5+ bxa5 35. Qc6#) 33. c6 Qd5 (33...Nf5 34. Qd3#) 34. Qb7+ Kb5 35. Qxa8 +-.
29... Nd5 30. Rf7+ Kc6 31. Qa4+ Kxc5 32. b4+ Nxb4 33. Rc7+ +-.
I guess it is lost...
